The typical working range for each setting is marked red, while the dotted lines indicate the switching points between the settings.Fig. 18
(Left) Photodiode calibration curve for the mid-range parameter set. Black dots: measured values extracted from the external energy sensor and the LPU log files (photodiode voltage). Red continuous line: linear fit to the dataset. Dashed/dotted red lines: maximum relative calibration uncertainty of ± 2% estimated from the data distribution. (Right) Overview of calibration curves for all three chosen sets of photodiode (PD) parameters. Red marked sections on curves: typical working ranges. Dotted horizontal lines: defined switching points between settings

As the result of an optimized optical layout of the monitoring stage, in combination with high-resolution sampling inside the LPU, an overall high accuracy of the photodiode measurement has been achieved. The LPU offers a detection up to a maximum photodiode output voltage of 4095 mV with 1 mV resolution, which translates to an energy measurement resolution between 0.05 µJ (upper energy range) and < 0.01 µJ (lowest energy range). The measured calibration curve in the left graph of Fig. 18 shows only minor deviations of the data from its linear fit. This proves the successful reduction of etalon effects inside the monitoring stage, which has been achieved by a careful design of all relevant dielectric coatings. The dashed and dotted lines added to the dataset indicate the maximum relative calibration uncertainty of ± 2% as estimated from the underlying data distribution.

The same high accuracy is achieved for energies in the upper range of the output energies (≈ 55 µJ and above). For the lowest output energies between 5 and 20 µJ the relative uncertainty is slightly higher with up to ± 5%. This is due to fairly low signal levels requiring high gain settings on the one hand and the higher relative influence of data quantization from the external energy sensor on the other hand.

During operations of the MOMA instrument, the rover’s control software automatically selects the appropriate photodiode setting based on the set temperature of the FCS, i.e., the expected output energy. With the corresponding calibration formula, the UV output energy is calculated from the measured photodiode voltage accordingly.

sec.title: Beam profile at sample location
sec.p: A detailed measurement of the beam profile across the full energy tuning range was performed at a distance behind the LH representing the MOMA LDMS sample location inside the UCZ. Due to the close proximity between this sample location and the LH, this measurement had to be performed prior final assembly of the LH into its sealed housing, i.e., with the fully integrated LH including monitoring stage and beam shaping lenses but excluding the main part of its housing (beam output side) and the beam deflection unit sub-assembly. The presence of those parts would otherwise not have provided sufficient clearance for the required beam profile measurement setup. All measurements have been acquired at an angle of incidence of 0° towards the UV-converter of the CCD camera. However, the inclined incidence onto the sample results in an increased effective beam diameter along the Y-axis (camera coordinates) by a factor of 1.39.

In Fig. 19, the images (a–f) show the evolution of the spatial beam profile during energy tuning via a variation of the FCS temperature. The corresponding pulse energy values can be found in Fig. 17.Fig. 19
Spatial UV beam profiles across full energy tuning range, i.e., as a function of frequency conversion stage temperature (TFCS). a corresponds to the maximum output energy of > 130 µJ, while f is showing the beam profile at E < 13 µJ (1 Hz operation). Arbitrary intensity scale, i.e., not related to actual output energy in favor of signal optimization on camera. Errors are given as the 3σ-values of the underlying dataset of 60 measurements per setting

Especially at the low FCS temperatures, i.e., high UV output energies, the slightly elliptical laser spot has a nearly Gaussian shape. The deviation from this Gaussian profile increases for the lower output energies since a side lobe along the major beam axis occurs, resulting from the induced phase mismatch especially in case of the more temperature-sensitive BBO crystal. However, most of the energy is still concentrated in the main spot, which can be well approximated by a Gaussian fit curve. Thus, all values stated for the beam size in Figs. 19 and 20 are given as the 1/e2-diameters of the Gaussian fits applied to the measured beam profiles.Fig. 20
Beam diameters at the sample location across the FCS temperature range. Calculated via Gaussian fits applied to the measured spatial UV beam profiles (1/e2 values)

In Fig. 20, the evolution of the measured beam diameters at the sample location across the FCS temperature range is shown. In addition, the effective beam diameter is included in the graph, which is calculated as the square root of the product of X and Y diameters. With the exception of the last data point (TFCS = 55 °C), the effective beam diameter stays within 10% deviation from its targeted specification across the entire tuning range.

sec.title: Temporal pulse profile and pulse duration
sec.p:
The temporal pulse profile has been characterized over a wide temperature tuning range of the FCS as well. The pulse duration is defined as the full width at half maximum (FWHM) value of the temporal pulse profile, which typically has a nearly Gaussian shape with a slight wing on its falling edge (see left graph in Fig. 21). To achieve reproducible measurements, two diffusors in front of an external ultrafast photodetector (Alphalas UPD-50-UP, < 40 ps rise time) ensure that the measured pulse duration is an average value for the whole spatial beam profile. In accordance with ISO 5 cleanliness requirements, an oscilloscope card (ZTEC/Teradyne ZT4611, 1 GHz bandwidth, 4 GS/s) was used that was incorporated into a cleanroom-compatible computer system. The setup enables to resolve a 1 ns pulse with less than 0.1 ns deviation of the measured FWHM with respect to the actual temporal pulse shape, which has also been verified experimentally. Due to the limited bandwidth, significantly shorter phenomena, such as mode beating, could not be resolved with this measurement setup.Fig. 21
(Left) Typical temporal pulse profile at 266 nm wavelength and 132 µJ pulse energy. Interpolated photodiode trace. (Right) Measured average pulse durations (FWHM) as a function of the FCS temperature. The error bars represent the standard deviation (1σ) of the underlying dataset of approx. 10 measurements per setting

In the right graph of Fig. 21, the average pulse durations for five different FCS temperature settings are shown. Typical FWHM pulse durations are in the range of approx. 1.4–1.6 ns, with the shorter durations at the maximum output energies and a tendency towards 15% higher values in case of the minimum specified output energy of the LH. Knowledge about the variation of the pulse duration across the tuning range is important to calculate the actual peak irradiance on the sample for different output energies of the LH and, therefore, properly assess data acquired during LDMS measurements.

sec.title: Qualification, integration and testing
sec.p: To prove compliance with the demanding environmental conditions during a mission to Mars, an extensive qualification and test program, configured as a protoflight approach, was developed for the MOMA laser system. Therefore, the major tests such as thermal vacuum cycling, vibration as well as shock testing have been performed with the actual FM laser according to the requirements and test loads as given in Table 1.

The space compatibility of many of the optical, electronic and mechanical components utilized within the LH has been confirmed via literature data or space heritage. Examples in this category are Nd:Cr:YAG, Nd:Ce:YAG, Cr:YAG, fused silica and the ISL71590SEHVF temperature transducer. Wherever the corresponding data were not available or were considered to be insufficient, the conformance with the radiation requirements defined for MOMA (see Table 1) has been proven via proton and/or gamma irradiation tests. This applies to several components of the LH, namely KTP, BBO, LaK9G15 glass, NG9, Sapphire, the modified UVG12 photodiodes (sealed with window caps) as well as several magnetron-sputtered optical coatings. All tested components were found to be uncritical with respect to the radiation levels defined for the MOMA instrument.

While high-energy UV laser systems in general are demanding with respect to cleanliness during assembly and testing, this is especially true in view of the exceptional reliability requirements connected with an application in space (2 million shots in case of the MOMA laser). Therefore, all final cleaning and inspection processes as well as the FM and FS assembly have taken place in a well-controlled ISO 5 cleanroom environment. In addition to fulfilling strict requirements with respect to the maximum number of particles per unit volume, the cleanroom is also equipped with filters for airborne molecular contamination (AMC filters ICF-BCD and ICF-ACD, M + W Products). During the entire assembly phase of the FM and FS lasers the cleanliness in the corresponding work area was monitored by means of witness plates dedicated to the detection of particulate and molecular contamination.

As part of the qualification program, extensive lifetime tests on component level have been conducted in a representative lab setup with both APM and FM optics. Examples are the operation of the entire oscillator sub-assembly for more than 65 million shots and a KTP subjected to > 22 million shots. These tests have been performed at 2–3 times the energies present in the FM/FS, i.e., with a setup optimized for an initially higher output energy specification. Furthermore, both KTP and BBO crystals from the FM lots have been subjected to > 1.5 million shots in a laser configuration with 190 µJ of UV output energy, i.e., approx. 50% above the energy levels of the FM and FS lasers. Extended tests have also been performed with the fully assembled and hermetically sealed FM laser without any sign of degradation (within the scope of the laser characterization and qualification campaign according to chapters 3 and 4).

All critical optical components, i.e., those exposed to high optical fluences, have undergone extensive stand-alone qualification tests as well. LIDT tests (S-on-1 or R-on-1 according to ISO 21254-2) have been performed to prove the general suitability of optics, coatings and their corresponding manufacturing lots for this special application. Representative witness samples have been used for this purpose where appropriate. Subsequent to an initial cleaning procedure, flight optic candidates have been selected by means of thorough visual inspection for contamination, defects and imperfections at high magnifications of typically ≥ 100×. Where necessary, further precision cleaning steps followed by repeated inspections have been performed. In addition, each critical flight optic has undergone a non-destructive raster scan test at an elevated fluence, similar to the approach already used for the ALADIN laser on the ADM-Aeolus satellite operating at 355 nm wavelength [35]. Here, the optic was irradiated with a test laser while scanning the beam across the relevant area with typically 90% overlap of the irradiation sites. This specific qualification test ensures that no microscopic defects or damage precursors would lead to laser-induced damages, e.g., due to absorption of high intensity UV laser radiation. Only such optics have been used for FM and FS integration that did not show any form of degradation or defect during the final microscopic inspection following their corresponding raster scan test.

Further details on the overall design verification methodology and qualification tests on component and sub-assembly level applied to both FM and FS lasers can be found in [36]. A major part of the qualification program especially for spaceflight hardware is environmental testing, i.e., a representative emulation of the mechanical and thermal loads that the instrument will experience during launch, cruise and landing of the spacecraft, as well as during its mission operations on Mars. Consequently, the MOMA lasers have been environmentally tested at multiple stages of the assembly process. As an intermediate verification on sub-assembly level, several vibrational and thermal cycling tests were performed prior subsequent assembly steps of the LH. After completion of the entire assembly process, the FM laser has then undergone an extensive stand-alone environmental test campaign, including vibration, shock and thermal vacuum (TVAC) tests (see test results in Sects. 4.1 and 4.3). Given the fact that the mechanical load levels had been precisely simulated and defined for the mounting interface of the MS, the LH was installed on a Structural Test Unit (STU, provided by GSFC) of the MS for both vibration and shock tests. That way, most representative test conditions could be achieved for the LH. The setups for vibration and TVAC testing are shown in Fig. 22. A more detailed description of the environmental test campaign can be found in [23]. In compliance with the protoflight approach followed for the qualification campaign, the FM laser system was tested up to the given environmental requirements. Minor extensions to both operational and survival temperature ranges have been applied during TVAC testing to add some margin of safety (see also test levels in Table 1).Fig. 22
Setups for the MOMA FM laser environmental testing at MPS. (Left) Bagged MS STU with FM LH on shaker for vibration testing. Inset shows unbagged hardware before the test. (Right) MOMA FM laser system (LH and LPU) in thermal vacuum chamber prior to their extensive TVAC test

To ensure compliance with the performance specifications for the LH, various characteristic laser parameters have been monitored during the entire test campaign. This included the output energy versus the FCS temperature (energy tuning behavior), the pulse release time, as well as beam shape and lateral position at the sample location. While these checks have been executed before and after vibration and shock tests, the performance of the MOMA FM laser system has also been tested under various thermal conditions and Mars-like atmosphere. During the corresponding TVAC test campaign, the laser system was subjected to two survival cycles between −55 and +60 °C, while three cycles were performed across the operational range between −45 and +25 °C including pulse energy and beam pointing measurements at intermediate steps. In addition to testing under vacuum, several measurements have also been performed under 6–10 mbar of CO2 to simulate the thermal conditions on Mars.

After successful completion of this initial environmental test campaign, the FM laser was delivered to NASA’s GSFC and integrated to the Flight Model of the MOMA MS subsystem, including a preliminary mockup of the UCZ (referred to as pseudo-UCZ), see left picture in Fig. 23. As a part of this integration process, the LH was mounted on the side wall of the MS housing and the LPU was mechanically and electrically connected to the MEB of the instrument (see gold-colored box behind LPU) on an elevated deck of the corresponding test and transport structure. The pseudo-UCZ, a preliminary sample compartment, featured a sample wheel containing various calibration and reference targets for LDMS operations, as well as a fluorescence plate for monitoring of the beam position. As a trade-off between a high damage threshold on the one hand and an adequate fluorescence signal on the other hand, a certain type of fused silica was selected as the material of choice for the fluorescence plate (Heraeus Infrasil 301, OH content < 8 ppm). A vacuum-compatible camera system (developed and provided by LZH) allowed imaging of the fluorescence signal generated inside this fused silica plate by the UV radiation emitted from the LH. With the aid of this camera, the LH deflection prism was precisely adjusted to optimize the laser beam position with respect to both the MS ion inlet and the nominal sample surface, i.e., centered to the projection of the ion inlet’s center axis onto the sample surface. As the last integration step, the beam deflection unit of the LH (see Fig. 11), being a separate volume that had to be accessed for the beam alignment process, was purged with dry synthetic air and finally hermetically sealed by means of four sealing screws equipped with specially designed gold foil seals.Fig. 23
Different stages along the instrument's integration process. (Left) FM laser system (LH and LPU connected with optical fiber) integrated to the MOMA Flight Model MS subsystem at GSFC and mounted on a temporary structure for further environmental testing and transport. LH marked with red box. (Right) MOMA fully integrated on both structural decks of Analytical Lab Drawer (ALD) package at TAS-I. Pictures by LZH with courtesy of GSFC, TAS-I and ESA

Following these integration activities, the performance of the FM laser system in combination with the MS was verified by means of several LDMS measurements on different calibration and reference targets. A comparison with data previously generated on the precursor model, the so-called Engineering Test Unit (ETU) of the MOMA instrument [18] including the ETU LH (see also Sect. 1.4), proved nominal performance of the FM instrument and, therefore, a successful completion of the MOMA laser integration process. The sequence of the extensive integration and test activities, including further testing on instrument as well as rover level, is illustrated in Fig. 24.Fig. 24
Flow chart of the sequence of integration activities including all environmental tests and laser checks. C: laser characterization including energy tuning curves measured with an external sensor and beam pointing measurements. H: laser health check including energy measurements via the LH-internal UV photodiode

In addition to the aforementioned integration and test activities at GSFC, LZH and MPS provided further support during the following critical stages of the integration process, e.g., for handling of the optical pump fiber between LPU and LH, for electrical checks, as well as regarding the supervision of environmental tests. As a next major step after the final assembly of MOMA, additional vibration and thermal cycling tests on instrument level were performed. LDMS measurements were conducted under Mars-analog atmosphere and at different temperature settings mimicking the environmental conditions on the Red Planet. In addition, laser checkouts were performed at different stages of the test campaign (see test results in Sects. 4.2 and 4.3). After successful testing on instrument level, MOMA was integrated into the ALD at TAS-I (see right picture of Fig. 23) and went through another high level TVAC test. Next, the ALD was integrated into the Rosalind Franklin rover at Airbus Defence and Space (ADS, Stevenage, UK). Further tests on rover level at another ADS site in Toulouse (France) included an acoustic test as well as another TVAC. The sequence of tests was completed by an electromagnetic interference and compatibility test (EMI/EMC) with active operation of different instruments. In this context, the performance of the MOMA laser system, i.e., the UV energy tuning curve, was checked again and the laser was approved for its journey to Mars.
In the following sections of chapter 4, various qualification test data for the MOMA FM laser system are presented, followed by some selected data from FS testing in chapter 5 for comparison.

sec.title: UV output energy before and after initial stand-alone environmental testing
sec.p:
Throughout the extensive qualification test campaign, the evolution of the UV output energy and the energy tuning behavior of the FM LH have been monitored repeatedly. The following data represent measurements prior environmental testing, after each major test sequence as well as after shipment to GSFC. All the data have been acquired with a calibrated external energy sensor. In the left graph of Fig. 25, the relevant energy tuning curves for 1 Hz operation of the LH are shown. While both vibration and shock testing did not have significant influence on the performance of the LH, small changes to the shape of the tuning curve have been observed after the TVAC test. While the maximum output energy decreased by less than 10%, increased output energies have been observed for the lower part of the energy tuning range. As no significant changes have been detected regarding the pulse release time of the oscillator, the observed performance deviations may be attributed to settling effects in the mounting mechanism of the nonlinear frequency conversion crystals.Fig. 25
(Left) Tuning curves of FM LH: UV output energy as a function of the FCS temperature at 1 Hz continuous operation before and after environmental testing. Datasets listed in the caption are in chronological order. (Right) Energy evolution at nominal maximum and minimum output energy set points in burst mode (10 PP/10 MP) throughout the test campaign

The nominal maximum and minimum output energy set points have also been tested for burst mode (10 PP/10 MP), i.e., the representative mode for actual MOMA LDMS science runs. The corresponding data for operation at the nominal minimum and maximum set temperature of the FCS are presented in the right graph of Fig. 25. Despite the aforementioned change in tuning behavior after the TVAC test, the LH still fulfilled its performance requirements with respect to the specified energy tuning range after the complete stand-alone environmental test campaign.

In the left graph of Fig. 26, the UV tuning curves for four different environmental temperatures during the initial stand-alone TVAC test of the laser system are presented. While these measurements have been performed at 1 Hz operation, additional data points in burst mode have been collected for TFCS = 35 °C and TFCS = 55 °C, i.e., the standard set points for maximum and minimum output energy. These data are shown in the right graph of Fig. 26. In comparison, the UV energy is typically 5–10% higher when operating the laser in burst mode. In a cold environment, the FM LH experiences a shift of the tuning curve towards higher output energies which can be partially accounted for by a corresponding change of the FCS temperature set point. Therefore, tuning to the lowest required output energies is still possible. Around the maximum output energy setting, this effect is also connected with a reversible change of the shape of the tuning curve. While the maximum output energy requirement is slightly missed at the most extreme environmental conditions, it is worth to mention that the LH will most likely experience warmer interfacial temperatures during typical operation scenarios. Due to the fact that MOMA is located inside the ALD, i.e., not in close proximity to the outer walls of the rover, and the MS housing as the mounting interface of the LH is heated up prior LDMS operations, interfacial temperatures below −20 °C are unlikely to be seen. Therefore, the LH is expected to meet its energy tuning specifications in all realistic scenarios.Fig. 26
(Left) UV output energy as a function of the FCS temperature for four different environmental temperatures (T_env) during TVAC testing at 1 Hz continuous operation. (Right) UV output energy as a function of the environmental temperature for two different FCS temperatures in burst mode (10 PP/10 MP)

sec.title: UV output energy evolution through further integration and testing
sec.p: The post-shipment test at GSFC (last dataset in both graphs of Fig. 25) marks the last output energy measurement taken with an external energy sensor. After integration of the LH to the MS, the UV beam could not be accessed with an external sensor any more. Thus, further data are solely based on values acquired with the calibrated LH-internal UV photodiode (see Sect. 3.4).

Further checks of the LH performance were carried out after vibration as well as TVAC testing at GSFC (on instrument level) and after shipment of the MOMA instrument to TAS-I. After integration of MOMA, another TVAC test on ALD level at TAS-I, as well as acoustic, TVAC and EMI/EMC tests on rover level at ADS (Toulouse) have been performed. Following this sequence of tests, the last full LH energy tuning curve before the launch of the ExoMars mission was measured. All corresponding datasets, acquired in burst mode operation, are shown in Fig. 27.Fig. 27
Tuning curves of FM LH: UV output energy as a function of FCS temperature throughout instrument integration activities and further environmental testing. Operation in burst mode. Datasets listed in the caption are in chronological order

The measurements revealed minor changes of the output energy throughout the entire test campaign. The maximum output energy decreased by less than 10%, still being very close to the specified maximum value of 125 µJ. At the low end of the tuning range, an increase by < 4% was observed. In combination with the effective beam diameter being approx. 8% below the specified value of 400 µm, a maximum output energy slightly below the specification is not an issue for MOMA, as still sufficiently high peak irradiances can be achieved. At the low end of the tuning range a further increase of the FCS temperature allows for output energies well below the specified minimum value of 12.5 µJ (see trend in Fig. 27; measured up to TFCS = 59 °C only for the first two datasets).

sec.title: Beam pointing throughout test campaign
sec.p: Another precondition for stable and reproducible measurements with the MOMA instrument is the stability of the laser beam position. To ensure an optimum LDMS signal level, the area of the sample irradiated by the UV laser has to stay within the core field of view of the MS ion inlet. The corresponding LH beam alignment budget is ± 500 µm relative to the center axis of the MS ion inlet after integration and final beam alignment. To proof the capabilities of the laser design with respect to beam stability, the laser beam position was monitored throughout the LH qualification campaign as well as the following integration activities and tests on instrument level at NASA’s GSFC.

During its initial test campaign, the LH was mounted on a solid titanium reference block, which featured an integrated mount for a fluorescence plate, representing the nominal sample location below the MOMA instrument. The position of the fluorescence spot, generated by the 266 nm beam inside this fused silica plate, was monitored with a camera system, and the relative beam movement was calculated with respect to a mechanical detail of the rigid reference block. The overall referencing and measurement accuracy through all tests is estimated to be in the order of ± 25 µm, including the influence of recurring adjustments to the pointing measurement setup between the tests. Measurements were taken before and after critical environmental tests and shipments as well as during the TVAC test sequence. Figure 28 shows a picture of the LH mounted on its reference block, the coordinate system applied to the beam position measurement, a detail view of the fluorescence plate mount and a sample fluorescence image.Fig. 28
(Left) FM LH mounted on solid titanium reference block for beam position measurements before and after vibration and shock tests as well as during TVAC. Coordinate system in yellow. Inset: sample fluorescence image, 44° AOI. (Right) Detail view of fluorescence plate mounted at the nominal sample position

A summary of the acquired beam pointing data is shown in Fig. 29. The measurements have to be split into two groups for further discussion: (a) stand-alone test campaign of the LH prior to its integration to the MS (left of blue dashed line) and (b) tests on MOMA instrument level following the integration of the LH to the MS (right of blue dashed line in Fig. 29).Fig. 29
Beam position evolution throughout test campaign and integration activities. To the left of blue dashed line: data acquired during qualification testing (incl. vibe, shock and TVAC) and prior integration to MS at GSFC. Blue dashed line: beam position optimization to MS ion inlet during integration—as scheduled. To the right of blue dashed line: evolution of beam position until last possible measurement at TAS-I prior integration of MOMA into ALD

As the exact locations of sample and MS ion inlet within the MOMA instrument are governed by a number of mechanical tolerances, for standalone tests of the LH the beam position was only roughly aligned to its theoretical target value with a desired accuracy of ± 500 µm in X and Y prior to the test campaign. While the beam position proved to be very stable in the X-direction, especially when considering the ± 25 µm measurement accuracy, more significant drifts have been observed in the Y-direction in particular after the shock and the TVAC test—adding up to a total movement in the Y-direction of almost 500 µm throughout the entire test campaign prior integration to the MS. Following those tests, detailed analyses of the data and all relevant mechanical sub-assemblies were performed with the goal to limit prospective beam drifts in the Y-direction to significantly lower values. As a result, the buildup of restraints during the final alignment of the deflection prism has been identified as one root cause of the observed phenomenon. Consequently, an improvement of the prism alignment strategy has been developed and subsequently implemented into the procedure for the integration of the LH into the MOMA instrument at GSFC.

The second part of the beam pointing data has been acquired after integration of the LH to the MS and prior integration of the MOMA instrument into the Analytical Lab Drawer (ALD) of the rover. In this configuration, the beam position was monitored by means of the aforementioned fluorescence plate on the sample wheel and the corresponding vacuum-compatible camera system connected to the pseudo-UCZ. The same setup was employed during the TVAC test of the entire MOMA instrument to monitor the beam position at various stages within the test sequence.

The blue dashed line in Fig. 29 marks this LH integration event together with the scheduled realignment of the laser beam to compensate for various mechanical tolerances within the instrument. At this time, the beam position was optimized with respect to both MS ion inlet and sample surface. The values in Fig. 29 are given as deviations from this optimum position. While on the Y-axis a zero deviation is optimum, a correction value of +305 µm had to be applied for the X-axis to account for the properties of the employed fluorescence-based position measurement in combination with an inclined incidence towards the sample location.

Following the integration activities, further vibration and TVAC tests have been performed on instrument level. These tests resulted in significantly lower beam drifts as during the initial qualification campaign of the LH. For the corresponding thermal cycling of the instrument, the environmental temperatures ranged between −55 and +50 °C. Here, the reduction of the upper limit as compared to the previous stand-alone TVAC test of the laser system (up to +60 °C) has been justified by more recent thermal simulations. Although this second TVAC test was significantly more demanding for the hardware than the initial one in terms of the number of cycles, a beam movement along the Y-direction of only 26% as compared to the previous test has been observed (7 vs. 2 full cycles between the maximum non-operational temperature extremes, plus several more cycles with intermediate temperature levels).

For more insight, data from various measurements during this second TVAC test are shown in Fig. 30. The corresponding measurements have been performed at different environmental/interfacial temperatures between −45 and +25 °C. In the left graph of Fig. 30, the first and the last data points (#1 and #26, marked with circles) are examples for comparable measurements at an environmental temperature of +25 °C. The dataset for the Y-direction indicates a small drift at the beginning of the TVAC test (approx. until measurement #13) followed by a fluctuation around an average offset of 80 µm. The results give good confidence that the amount of beam movement along the Y-direction not only has significantly decreased as compared to the initial and shorter TVAC test, but also a settling to a stable beam position has been achieved.Fig. 30
(Left) Beam position measurements during the second TVAC test at GSFC (instrument level). Performed at various environmental/interfacial temperatures between −45 and +25 °C. Empty squares: X-values corrected for reversible effects resulting from varying environmental temperatures. (Right) Beam position as a function of the LH body temperature near the prism showing the expected dependence along the X-axis

Furthermore, the test did not reveal any significant irreversible change in the X-direction. The reversible changes within a range of about 200 µm were expected and occurred due to the temperature dependent refractive index of the fused silica prism that is used for 44° deflection of the beam towards the sample location. As the temperature of the laser housing part containing the prism was logged during the tests as well, these data have been used to calculate X-values corrected for the influence of the varying environmental temperature. The resulting dataset (empty squares in the left graph of Fig. 30) shows a residual variation of approx. ± 50 µm around the target value without indications of a thermally induced irreversible drift. In the right graph of Fig. 30, the beam position is plotted as a function of the aforementioned LH body temperature. As expected, the beam movement along the X-axis correlates well with temperature while no significant dependence has been found for the Y-axis.

The last measurement of the beam position has been performed at TAS-I (see last data point #26 in the left graph of Fig. 30), right before marriage of the instrument with the UCZ and the following integration into the ALD. Due to the lack of fluorescence plate and camera at this stage, further beam pointing checks have not been possible. However, the performance of MOMA was regularly checked via LDMS tests on calibration targets, to make sure the instrument continued to stay healthy through the course of several following environmental tests.

sec.title: Flight spare performance and testing
sec.p: Built from identical parts and adopting the same assembly processes as for the FM, the FS LH largely represents the FM in terms of its optical performance. As such, it will support the ExoMars mission as part of a testbed system at GSFC for various testing and troubleshooting purposes (see also Sect. 1.4).

During FS assembly an increased amount of intermediate TVAC tests on sub-assembly level as well as vibration tests of oscillator and frequency conversion stage have been performed. With these additional measures, mechanical settling effects were induced already early in the assembly process and, therefore, could be compensated for during later steps of its build phase. For its final qualification a slightly reduced test campaign has been derived considering its solely ground-based application. As part of the MOMA testbed instrument, the FS laser will experience thermal cycling under a Mars-like atmosphere, but not the mechanical loads like the FM during launch, cruise and landing. Therefore, it was decided to omit shock and vibration tests for the FS, while a thorough thermal cycling campaign has been conducted, same as for the FM. In case the FS needs to be considered for flight again, the omitted tests would be performed at a later time accordingly.
In this chapter, a short summary of the FS performance and testing is presented.

sec.title: FS UV beam profile
sec.p:
Typical UV beam profiles measured at a distance behind the laser representing the sample location are shown in Fig. 31—both for FS and FM. Compared to the FM, the axes of the elliptical beam profile are rotated by approx. 20° and the beam diameters are slightly smaller. While the beam shape is governed by the final alignment of the oscillator’s output coupler and the nonlinear crystals, deviations in beam diameter can be attributed to component tolerances, e.g., of the pump lenses, of components inside the oscillator or the beam shaping telescope. Considering the short focal lengths of the telescope lenses, even small deviations from their nominal specification have a measurable impact on the size of the output beam.Fig. 31
Comparison of typical UV beam profiles at the sample distance. 1 Hz operation. (Left) FS LH at an output energy of 133 µJ and (right) FM LH at 138 µJ

sec.title: FS UV pulse durations
sec.p:
In Fig. 32, a typical temporal pulse profile of the UV output is shown together with the measured pulse durations (FWHM) as a function of the FCS temperature—both in comparison to values acquired with the FM. The FS pulse durations as well as their evolution during energy tuning are very similar to the FM with an approx. 0.1 ns offset to smaller values for the FS. Considering the uncertainties connected with the corresponding test setup, especially regarding the averaging across the spatial beam profile, the deviation is within the systematic error of the measurement. However, a more detailed analysis has not been performed in the context of the FS qualification process.Fig. 32
(Left) Typical temporal UV pulse profile of FS LH (E = 133 µJ) vs. FM LH (E = 132 µJ). Interpolated photodiode traces. (Right) FS vs. FM pulse duration (FWHM) as a function of the FCS temperature. The error bars represent the standard deviation (1σ) of the underlying dataset of approx. 10 measurements per setting

sec.title: FS UV pulse energy and beam position during TVAC testing
sec.p:
Similar to the FM test campaign, an extensive TVAC test was performed with the FS laser system, with slight adjustments to the thermal profile and the sequence of performance measurements as lessons learned from the FM qualification. In total, the test comprised four full temperature cycles between +60 and −55 °C, with 21 measurements of the output energy and the beam pointing being performed at different stages within the sequence. In the left graph of Fig. 33, the output energy tuning curves before shipment to the test site at MPS, before and after the TVAC test as well as after shipment back to LZH are presented for laser operation at 1 Hz repetition rate (averaged values). The output energy performance proved to be very stable against thermal cycling, i.e., no significant changes could be measured. After TVAC testing, the nominal oscillator temperature set points have been optimized based on test results regarding thermal stabilization at various environmental conditions. This resulted in a slight overall increase in output energy. The right graph of Fig. 33 shows the final performance of the FS LH for burst operation (3 PP/5 MP) after delivery to GSFC, as well as the corresponding FM tuning curve for comparison (also post-shipment at GSFC). Slight differences in the shape of the tuning curve and the chosen temperature set points originate from deviations between both models regarding the final alignment of the nonlinear frequency conversion crystals.Fig. 33
(Left) FS tuning curves: UV output energy as a function of the FCS temperature before and after TVAC test. 1 Hz operation. (Right) Tuning curves of FS and FM for burst mode operation (3 PP/5 MP), both measured after delivery to GSFC

In case of the FS, the energy tuning curve is steeper and, therefore, allows to reach lower output energies within the defined range of FCS temperatures. This compensates the aforementioned differences in beam diameter so that the range of possible intensities on the sample is the same as for the FM.

During the TVAC test, the beam position was monitored by means of a fluorescent fused silica plate at the nominal sample location—in analogy to the FM investigations. In the left graph of Fig. 34, only the beam positions measured at a chamber/interface temperature of +25 °C are shown to waive the (known) reversible temperature effects for the evaluation of the overall beam position stability of the FS LH with respect to thermal cycling (see also Sect. 4.3). Measurements at both atmospheric pressure (air, 1 bar) and vacuum are included for purposes of a broad database.Fig. 34
(Left) Beam position measurements during the FS TVAC test campaign at MPS, performed at +25 °C chamber/interface temperature; TFCS = 36 °C; air (1 bar) vs. vacuum. Thermal cycling: four full cycles from +60 to −55 °C between M02 and M24. M22 chosen as reference (= zero shift). (Right) Evolution of beam position until delivery to GSFC. Last measurement chosen as reference

Considering the underlying referencing and measurement accuracy of approx. ± 25 µm, the beam position proved to be very stable during the TVAC test, with a measured fluctuation along the Y-axis of less than 20 µm. The beam position along the X-axis also depends on the refraction at the deflection prism and the UCZ window (present in the test), both being influenced by temperature and surrounding atmosphere. With respect to the presented test data, only the influence of the chamber pressure on the refraction at the UCZ window is relevant, as the prism is surrounded by a constant atmosphere (sealed volume of deflection unit) and its temperature is approximately the same for each data point in the left graph of Fig. 34. The average beam shift between atmospheric pressure and vacuum conditions was measured to be 52 µm and is, therefore, in good agreement with the corresponding theoretical value of 56 µm. The fluctuation along the X-axis was in the range of 20–30 µm for both air and vacuum. The right graph of Fig. 34 shows the evolution of the beam position throughout the qualification test campaign until delivery to GSFC. With a maximum value of 30 µm along the X-axis, the measured shift of the beam position was only slightly above the estimated measurement accuracy.

Therefore, the presented FS test data prove the stability of the flight laser design against thermal cycling for a second time. With its performance closely resembling the Flight Model onboard the ExoMars rover, the FS laser system will enable representative LDMS studies with the MOMA testbed system at GSFC.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: We have given a comprehensive description of the development, manufacturing and qualification process of the UV Laser Head Flight Model for the MOMA instrument onboard ESA’s Rosalind Franklin rover. As the central part of the ExoMars mission, this semi-autonomous rover will introduce advanced technology to Mars, with the aim to search for biosignatures up to 2 m below the Martian surface. In this context, MOMA offers a unique combination of GCMS and LDMS techniques enabling the detection of a wide variety of both volatile and non-volatile, organic and inorganic molecules.

The MOMA UV laser is employed as an excitation source for the mass spectrometer subsystem of the instrument. The miniaturized LH has been developed and assembled at LZH in Hanover, Germany. The corresponding space-qualified electronics box (LPU) has been provided by MPS in Göttingen, Germany. Together, they represent the first 266 nm DPSS laser system to be sent to space. The highly robust, yet lightweight LH is based on a longitudinally diode-pumped, passively Q-switched Nd:Cr:YAG oscillator with subsequent two-stage frequency-quadrupling. It is capable of emitting intense UV pulses with durations around 1.5 ns and a pulse energy tunable between 12.5 and 125 µJ. The laser provides shot-to-shot pulse monitoring via an integrated photodiode, allowing to correlate measured LDMS data with the actual UV pulse energy fired onto the sample. Furthermore, the LH includes a built-in deflection unit based on an adjustable Brewster prism which is employed to precisely steer the beam towards the sample location below the MOMA instrument.

The MOMA FM laser system has been extensively tested with respect to the expected mechanical loads and environmental conditions during launch, cruise, landing and mission operations. The FM was qualified according to a protoflight approach including vibration and shock testing. Furthermore, its capability to operate at temperatures between −45 and +25 °C in a Mars-like atmosphere has been proven. Following a successful stand-alone test campaign, the laser was delivered to NASA’s GSFC for integration to the MOMA instrument. Further stations in preparation for its launch to Mars included integration and testing activities at TAS-I in Turin, ADS in Stevenage, ADS in Toulouse and TAS in Cannes. Throughout this process, all critical laser-related tasks were supported by LZH and MPS. Finally, the integration of all scientific instruments, including MOMA, into the Rosalind Franklin rover took place at ADS in Stevenage in August 2019, marking a major ExoMars milestone. During the extensive sequence of integration activities and qualification tests, the FM laser system demonstrated a stable performance with only minor deviations between the individual tests.

Furthermore, a second model based on the flight LH design, named Flight Spare, was assembled, thoroughly tested and finally delivered to GSFC for future ground-based testbed operations. As such, the FS closely mimics the performance of the FM. Both laser systems passed their extensive qualification test campaigns and, therefore, proved the space compatibility and ruggedness of the realized compact laser concept.

With respect to the application of the laser system, its output characteristics make it an ideal source for laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry, one of the two main modes of operation of the MOMA instrument. Tuning of the laser over a wide range of pulse energies enables a careful analysis of Martian soil samples. Measurements starting from low peak irradiances prevent undesired destruction of potentially sensitive molecular species of interest. The pulse energy can be continuously increased until sufficiently high ion counts from the mass spectrometer are achieved. The rover’s underlying software algorithms have been validated with previous prototypes of MOMA and will ensure that each sample will be analyzed with an optimized measurement sequence, individually tailored to the demands of its constituents.

MOMA will be the first laser-enabled mass spectrometer to be operated on another planet and is considered to be the most advanced instrument, to date, dedicated to the search for biosignatures on the Red Planet. These may provide important information related to the potential origin, evolution and distribution of extinct and/or extant life on Mars. With its variety of instruments on the rover as well as on the corresponding landing and surface science platform of the mission, ExoMars is also targeted to deliver further insight into questions about habitability, e.g., the identification and characterization of possible hazards for human exploration of the Red Planet.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful for the funding support throughout the project and towards the launch and operation of the ExoMars mission. The authors also acknowledge the support from their direct project partners MPS and GSFC and would like to thank them for a good and fruitful collaboration during the development, assembly, testing and integration of the MOMA laser system for ExoMars. Furthermore, the authors thank the team at GSFC for providing valuable data from the environmental test campaign of the MOMA flight instrument. Last but not least, the authors thank the entire MOMA team for their contributions throughout the project. Over the years, a large number of colleagues assisted and participated in the effort to build the first 266 nm diode-pumped solid-state laser to be sent to space.
